section.title: Dependency tree
section.p: By means of the dependency parser sme-dep.rle the CG output is turned into dependency trees. The root, which does not have a head it depends on, is marked by 0. The element that depends on the head is marked by an arrow pointing at 0 ("->0"). Each token gets a number (#) and the a dependency link specifying a target head (->). The second word in the sentence for example receives the number 2. If it is a dependent of the root, it gets the tag ("#2->0"). The CG verb tags are substitued with other tags. Here is an example:
section.source:
"<Muitaleastte>" "muitalit" V* TV Der2 Der/easti <mv> V Imprt Sg2 @FMV #1->0 "<fal>" "fal" Adv @<ADVL #2->1 "<munnje>" "mun" Pron Pers Sg1 Ill @<ADVL #3->1 "<goas>" "goas" Adv @ADVL> #4->7 "<doavttir>" "doavttir" N Sg Nom @SUBJ> #5->6 "<sáhttá>" "sáhttit" <aux> V IV Ind Prs Sg3 @FS-STA #6->1 "<boahtit>" "boahtit" <mv> V IV Inf @FS-IMV #7->6 "<.>" "." CLB #8->8
Muitaleastte / \ \ fal munnje \ sáhttá / \ doavttir boahtit. \ goas
section.p: Our dependency structure is based upon a compromise between the Sámi grammatical tradition and the conventions used within the visl project.

section.title: Verb tags
section.p: The Sámi disambiguation file sme-dep.rle adds dependency tags to each cohort. The CG verb tags are substituted with these tags:
There are main verbs and auxiliary verbs.
In main clauses: Finite main verb and auxiliary verb, and infinite main verb and auxiliary verb.
@FS is a finite verb in a subclause. The first one in a subclause which functions as a statement, the latter one in a relative subclause.
These are infinite main verbs and auxiliary verbs in an ordinary subclause and in a relative subclause.
This tag helps in coordination contexts.

section.title: Dependency tags alphabetically
section.p: Dependency tags look different than syntactic grammar tags.

dl.dd:
finite mainverb
lei
Gávpot lei njealječiegat, seammá guhkki go govdat.

subclause adverbial
bohtet
Ja mo jos Muhtinlágan Stálu ustibat bohtet fitnat.

subclause infinite mainverb
ohcamin
Naba jos eadni lea sudno ohcamin, iige gávnna.

finite verb of a (relative) subclause
lea
De son viežžá liegga liema ruittus mii lea oapmana alde. `Then he fetched warm broth from the pot that was on the stove.'

dd.em: Son lea njulgen čielggi, ja lea nuorra ja searra. `He has straightened his back and is young and strong.'

dl.dd:
(relative) subclause object
leahkkasii
Arne ii fuobmán ahte uksa leahkkasii. `Arne did not notice that the door opened.'

dd.em: Idja ii leat šat, eai ge sii dárbbaš lámppá dahje beaivváža čuovgga, dasgo Hearrá Ipmil lea sin čuovga.

dl.dd:
non-finite auxiliary
veaje
Dattetge ii veaje oađđit.

infinitival clause object
boradit
Muhtinlágan Stállu cáhpá goikebierggu sudnuide ja dáhttu mánáid boradit.

non-finite mainverb
Gávpotmuvrra vuođđogeađggit ledje čiŋahuvvon juohke lágán divrras geđggiiguin.

dd.em: Dat geahččá nuppiid stáluide girkes čalmmiiguin ja reašká romet.

dl.dd:
main verb, especially useful in cases where the verb can be both a main verb and an auxiliary
dárbbašit, oažžut
Danne dárbbašit mii oažžut lobi Nils Aslak Valkeapää árbbolaččain almmuhit dán guokte lávlaga min sálbma-CD:s.

verba dicendi, those that introduce direct speech, typically words of communication
celkkii
Eŋgel celkkii munnje: Dát leat luohtehahtti ja duohta sánit.

section.title: Coordination
section.p: Here are some examples of our coordination-analysis:
section.source:
"Náhkiin sii gorro roavgguid, dorkkaid ja gápmagiid."
gorro / | \ Náhkiin sii roavgguid, / \ doarkkaid gápmagiid. / ja
"Bárdni válddii niibbi ja čuohpai ráiggi sehkkii ja luittii mánáid olggos."
válddii_____ / / \ \ Bárdni niibbi \ luittii | čuohpai | \ ja / | mánáid olggos. / | ráiggi sehkkii | ja

section.title: Complex sentences
section.source:
"Jus stállu vuoitá, de son goddá olbmo."
vuoitá,__ / | \ \ Jus stállu de \ goddá / \ son olbmo.
"Dasto don it beasa ruoktot jus borat min luhtte."
it __ / | \ don beasa \ / \ \ Dasto ruoktot borat | \ jus luhtte. | min
No finite verb in the the second main clause: "Vuos galgá liinna seaktit, de suohpput ja nuppi iđida fas geassit dan."
galgá | seaktit, ___________ / | \ \ \ Vuos liinna de suohpput geassit | / | \ ja iđeda fas dan. / nuppi
No verb in the main clause: "Ovdal buorida Ipmil dálkkiidis go neavrres olmmoš dábiidis."
buorida _______ / | \ \ Ovdal Ipmil dálkkiidis \ olmmoš / | \ go neavrres dábiidis.

section.title: Punctuation
section.p: Punctuation such as ".", "," and ";" also receive dependency tags. The sentence "Arvigoahtá. - It starts raining" actually consists of two elements, the finite verb and the punctuation. The full stop is also interpreted as a dependent of the root "#2->0".

section.title: Arguments and adjuncts
section.p: Subcategorized arguments such as "beatnagis - of the dog" in the sentence "Balat go beatnagis? - Are you afraid of the dog" are interpreted as dependents of the finite verb. Right now, we do not distinguish between sentence adverbials (adjuncts) and subcategorized arguments. "Odne - today" in "Odne arvá. - Today, it rains." is also interpreted as a dependent of the verb.
